thread.title: Hornsby property developments being approved in excess of the state government target
thread.title_full: Hornsby property developments being approved in excess of the state government target | News Local

author: Nigel Gladstone
title: Hornsby property developments being approved in excess of the state government target
text:
Hornsby Mayor Steve Russell. Photo: Adam Ward Hornsby Hornsby property developments being approved in excess of the state government target Nigel Gladstone, Hornsby Advocate February 8, 2017 4:55pm
Hornsby has soared past its State Government property development targets by almost 4000 dwellings while Ku-ring-gai is 40 homes behind schedule, analysis of NSW planning data shows.
State Balmain Greens MP Jamie Parker, who commissioned the analysis , said Hornsby Council was 3792 dwellings ahead of its target and the “question is why the council has approved so many developments in excess of its housing target”.
Hornsby Mayor Steve Russell said the analysis was based on the wrong information.
“They used the approvals data, which don’t always translate into actual buildings,” Cr Russell said.
“While we may be ahead in approvals we’re not ahead in what’s being built.
“Units may get a DA but then they have to get finance to build the project.
“One notable example is (a site) opposite Westfield — that was approved six or seven years ago.
“We’re just meeting the targets now and I understand they are being revised upwards.”
Mr Parker acknowledged the lag between approvals and construction but was sceptical about the council’s justification for permitting thousands of dwellings more than planned by the State Government.
“For the council to take no responsibility for approving numbers well in excess of their target is quite extraordinary,” he said.
Cr Russell said demand for different types of housing such as townhouses and villas was not being met in Hornsby.
media_camera (L-R) John Townend, Alister Henskens SC MP, Harry Loughnan, James Watson, Russ Hooper and Michael Richardson after the NSW Department of Planning rejected Ku-ring-gai Council’s proposal to reclassify and sell the Culworth Ave car park at Killara, which could have become a multistorey residential development.
Ku-ring-gai state MP Alister Henskens said Ku-ring-gai was “an exemplar of how to integrate attractive housing in an environmentally sympathetic tree-lined setting”.
“We should praise the way in which Ku-ring-gai was properly planned and advocate for its preservation,” he said. “I will always fight for State Government policies that will preserve the unique character of Ku-ring-gai.”
A Ku-ring-gai Council spokeswoman said the council is meeting all current state government targets for housing growth.
“Between 2006 and 2016 the Council approved 8082 new dwellings,” she said. “It’s important to note that housing targets are not mandated by the government, but are projections for future housing.”
Factors that influence development in urban councils, apart from community consultation include bushfire prone land, access and the environment, she said.
State Labor MLC for Hornsby Greg Donnelly said Sydney’s expansion needs to be “distributed fairly across all communities, not just crammed into less well-off areas”.
“Every suburb across Sydney needs to do its fair share, but it seems like some councils are doing far more of the heavy lifting and others are getting off scot-free,” Mr Donnelly said.
“We need to be providing a diversity of housing types in a range of areas and not just cramming more people into apartment towers in select suburbs.”
Hornsby state MP Matt Kean did not respond to request for comments before deadline.
Hornsby dwellings approved / built:
2013/14: 1167 / 280
2014/15: 1911 / 587
2015/16: 3092 / 1171
Ku-ring-gai dwellings approved / built
2013/14: 865 / 397
2014/15: 523 / 528
2015/16: 1460 / 343
*Sources: ABS catalogue 8731.0 — Building Approvals and for built — NSW Dept. Planning — Net Dwelling Completions.
